references: We first compare the testing accuracies of DP2-FedSAM and baselines under various non-IID distribution settings with a fixed privacy budget of ϵ=1italic-ϵ1\epsilon=1. Fig. 4 illustrates the testing accuracies over communication rounds, while Table II summarizes the final average accuracy and standard deviation after T𝑇T rounds for all schemes. For CIFAR-10 dataset, the results are further segmented based on different combinations of the total number of clients N𝑁N and the number of classes each client possesses S𝑆S, i.e., (500,5)5005(500,5), (1000,2)10002(1000,2), and (1000,5)10005(1000,5).

As summarized in Table II, DP2-FedSAM outperforms other baselines across different heterogeneous settings. Specifically, DP2-FedSAM achieves an approximate 12% to 30% and 14% enhancement in accuracy over DP-FedAvg for CIFAR-10 and FEMNIST datasets, respectively. Our method consistently shows better performance compared to SOTA methods. For instance, it approximately improves the averaged testing accuracy by around 5% compared to DP-FedSAM-FT and by about 3% compared to CENTAUR.

S5.T3.caption: TABLE III: Testing accuracy (%) comparison under different privacy budgets. A smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon indicates a stronger privacy guarantee.
S5.T3.table:
Dataset FEMNIST CIFAR-10
ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon 1.0 2.0 1.0 2.0
DP-FedAvg 52.2±plus-or-minus\pm0.7 62.9±plus-or-minus\pm1.7 54.8±plus-or-minus\pm0.5 65.9±plus-or-minus\pm0.6
DP-FedAvg-FT 57.8±plus-or-minus\pm0.7 66.7±plus-or-minus\pm1.2 79.2±plus-or-minus\pm0.4 82.8±plus-or-minus\pm0.1

DP-FedSAM-FT 56.5±plus-or-minus\pm0.6 67.4±plus-or-minus\pm0.4 80.0±plus-or-minus\pm0.5 83.3±plus-or-minus\pm0.2
CENTAUR 59.3±plus-or-minus\pm0.4 69.6±plus-or-minus\pm0.7 81.5±plus-or-minus\pm0.6 83.1±plus-or-minus\pm0.5
DP2-FedSAM 66.7±plus-or-minus\pm0.7 72.2±plus-or-minus\pm0.4 84.1±plus-or-minus\pm0.6 85.3±plus-or-minus\pm0.8
references: Table III provides a comprehensive comparison of testing accuracy for different schemes under varying levels of privacy budget, as indicated by different values of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. For CIFAR-10, we conduct experiments under (N,S)=(1000,2)𝑁𝑆10002(N,S)=(1000,2). A lower value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon corresponds to a stronger privacy guarantee. The results demonstrate a clear trend where the DP2-FedSAM method consistently outperforms other methods across both FEMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets for all privacy budget settings. Notably, for the most restrictive privacy setting (ϵ=1.0italic-ϵ1.0\epsilon=1.0), DP2-FedSAM achieves the highest testing accuracies of 66.7% on FEMNIST and 84.1% on CIFAR-10, respectively. This trend persists across different values of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, suggesting the robustness of DP2-FedSAM in maintaining high accuracy under stringent privacy constraints.
